H0.text: Texture is the most reliable property for distinguishing one mineral from another in a lab investigation where students identified different mineral specimens.

H1.text: Hardness is the most reliable property for distinguishing one mineral from another in the lab investigation where students had to identify different mineral specimens.

H2.text: Crystal shape is the most reliable property for identifying one mineral from another in a lab investigation where students had to identify different mineral specimens.

H3.text: Surface color is the most reliable property for identifying one mineral from another in a lab investigation where students had to identify different mineral specimens.

A4.text: The Mohs scale is useful for identification of minerals in the field

A5.text: Hardness may be difficult to determine, or may be misleading or meaningless, if a material is a mixture of multiple substances.

A6.text: The Mohs scale is an ordinal scale.

A7.text: The Mohs scale is not an accurate predictor of how well materials endure in an industrial setting.

A8.text: Colour is the most obvious property of a mineral, but it is often non-diagnostic.

A9.text: The hardness of a mineral defines how much it can resist scratching or indentation.
